head.title: PadÃ© Interpolation: Methodology and Application to Quarkonium

article.h1:
PadÃ© Interpolation:
Methodology and Application to Quarkonium

span.span: C. N. Leung and J. A. Murakowski111Present address: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19716, U.S.A.

Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Delaware
Newark, DE 19716, U.S.A.

div.p: A novel application of the PadÃ© approximation is proposed in which the PadÃ© approximant is used as an interpolation for the small and large coupling behaviors of a physical system, resulting in a prediction of the behavior of the system at intermediate couplings. This method is applied to quarkonium systems and reasonable values for the cğ‘italic-cc and bğ‘italic-bb quark masses are obtained.

The PadÃ© approximation seeks to approximate the behavior of a function, fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)f(x), by a ratio of two polynomials of xğ‘¥italic-xx. This ratio is referred to as the PadÃ© approximant. Compared to the usual perturbative power series approximation, the PadÃ© approximant has the advantage that it deviates less rapidly from the true values of fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)f(x) as xğ‘¥italic-xx becomes large. Recently, the PadÃ© approximation has been applied to quantum field theories to estimate the next order term in a perturbation series[1]. The method involves calculating a certain physical quantity perturbatively to nğ‘›italic-nnth order in the coupling constant and then forming a PadÃ© approximant which, when expanded in a power series of the coupling constant, reproduces the perturbative result. The (n+1)ğ‘›1OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(n+1)th order term in the expansion of the PadÃ© approximant yields an estimate of the (n+1)ğ‘›1OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(n+1)th order term in the perturbation series for the physical quantity. It turns out one can obtain reasonably good estimates from this approach.

In this paper a different usage of the PadÃ© approximation is proposed. We observe that, because of the nature of the PadÃ© approximant, it can be expanded in a power series in xğ‘¥italic-xx when xğ‘¥italic-xx is small as well as in a power series in 1x1ğ‘¥FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-x ARG:end\frac{1}{x} when xğ‘¥italic-xx is large. It is therefore interesting to ask the question: in cases when both the small xğ‘¥italic-xx (e.g., weak coupling) and the large xğ‘¥italic-xx (e.g., strong coupling) behaviors of a theory can be computed perturbatively, is it possible to form a single PadÃ© approximant which interpolates the weak and strong coupling behaviors, and if so, how well does this PadÃ© interpolation approximate the behaviors of the theory at intermediate values of the coupling constant? This is a particularly timely question since, with the advance of duality in supersymmetric gauge theories[2], we may someday be able to compute the strong coupling behaviors of a theory from its dual theory. The PadÃ© interpolation will then provide a means to estimate the behaviors of the theory for the entire range of the coupling constant.

The method proposed here goes beyond interpolating the strong and weak coupling behaviors of a system. For example, the expansion parameter xğ‘¥italic-xx can be the temperature, the strength of an applied field, or, as discussed below in the application to heavy quarkonia, a parameter introduced to implement the PadÃ© interpolation.

We have tested the PadÃ© interpolation method with examples in which the exact result is known, with encouraging success. To see how accurate the PadÃ© interpolation can be and to illustrate the methodology involved, let us consider a simple quantum mechanical two-state system with the Hamiltonian,

semantics.annotation: italic-H RELOP:equals italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where the Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigmaâ€™s are the Pauli matrices and the coupling constant Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda is assumed to be positive. For Î»â‰ª1much-less-thanğœ†1italic-lambda RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1\lambda\ll 1, the Ïƒzsubscriptğœğ‘§italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{z} term may be treated as a perturbation and we find, to second order in perturbation theory, the eigenvalues of Hğ»italic-HH are

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus-or-minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus-or-minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: For Î»â‰«1much-greater-thanğœ†1italic-lambda RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1\lambda\gg 1, the Hamiltonian can be written as H=Î»â¢(Ïƒz+1Î»â¢Ïƒx)ğ»ğœ†subscriptğœğ‘§1ğœ†subscriptğœğ‘¥italic-H RELOP:equals italic-lambda OPEN:( italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-lambda ARG:end italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)H=\lambda(\sigma_{z}+\frac{1}{\lambda}\sigma_{x}), and the Ïƒxsubscriptğœğ‘¥italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{x} term can be treated as a perturbation. We find, again to second order in perturbation theory, the eigenvalues of Hğ»italic-HH are now

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus-or-minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-lambda ADDOP:plus-or-minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-lambda ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: A PadÃ© approximant which interpolates the small and large Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda behaviors of the energies can now be constructed. For the higher energy level E+subscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+}, we find

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( PA CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: This PadÃ© approximant is uniquely determined from the perturbative expansions for E+subscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+} given in (2) and (3). The large Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda behavior indicates that the polynomial in the numerator must be one degree higher than the polynomial in the denominator and that the coefficient for the highest order term in Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda must be the same for the two polynomials. Without loss of generality, we may choose this coefficient to be 1. If the numerator is a polynomial of degree dğ‘‘italic-dd, there will be a total of (2â¢d-1)2ğ‘‘1OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(2d-1) coefficients to be determined for the PadÃ© approximant. Because the small Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda behavior requires the numerator and the denominator to have the same constant (i.e., Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda-independent) term, there are only (2â¢d-2)2ğ‘‘2OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)(2d-2) remaining coefficients to be determined. Expanding the PadÃ© approximant and matching against the perturbation series in (2) and (3) provide an additional four conditions, which selects d=3ğ‘‘3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3.

In Figure 1, the approximate result generated from PadÃ© interpolation is compared with the exact result, E+=Î»2+1subscriptğ¸superscriptğœ†21italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 ARG:endE_{+}=\sqrt{\lambda^{2}+1}. We see that the PadÃ© approximant (open squares) tracks the exact result (solid curve) for all values of the coupling constant. In fact, E+(PA)superscriptsubscriptğ¸PAitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( PA CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endE_{+}^{(\rm PA)} differs from E+subscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+} by no more than about 1% for the entire range of Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda. For example, for Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda = 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 4.0, E+(PA)superscriptsubscriptğ¸PAitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( PA CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endE_{+}^{(\rm PA)} is larger than E+subscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+} by 0.63%, 1.02%, 0.62%, and 0.18%, respectively. One may improve the approximation by calculating more terms in the perturbation series for E+<subscriptsuperscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{<}_{+} and E+>subscriptsuperscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{>}_{+} and constructing the corresponding PadÃ© approximant. However, our example suffices to demonstrate the potential power of the PadÃ© interpolation method in that very few terms in the perturbation expansions can yield a very accurate approximation to the exact result for the entire range of the coupling constant.

For comparison, we have also plotted in Figure 1 the perturbative result for small Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda, E+<subscriptsuperscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{<}_{+} (dotted curve). As expected, it only agrees with the exact result for small values of Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda and diverges significantly from the exact result when Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda becomes large. Similarly, E+>subscriptsuperscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{>}_{+} will diverge from the exact result for small Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda. In contrast, by interpolating E+<subscriptsuperscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{<}_{+} and E+>subscriptsuperscriptğ¸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{>}_{+}, the PadÃ© approximant is constrained not to deviate too far from the exact result for the full range of the coupling constant. In this way, the PadÃ© interpolation method can yield a very good approximation, provided the quantity we try to approximate is a smooth, continuous function of the coupling constant.

When applying the PadÃ© interpolation, one should beware of potential unphysical singularities coming from the zeroes of the polynomial in the denominator of the PadÃ© approximant. This complication may limit the scope of applicability of the method. On the other hand, this property may prove useful in some applications. For instance, when interpolating the high and low temperature behaviors of a system for which a phase transition takes place at some intermediate temperature, one may try to construct a PadÃ©-like approximant (perhaps involving fractional powers in the polynomials) which mimics the singular behavior near the phase transition point.

Another way to implement the PadÃ© interpolation method is in cases when the Hamiltonian can be expressed as H=H1+H2ğ»subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2italic-H RELOP:equals italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH=H_{1}+H_{2}, where the exact solutions for H1subscriptğ»1italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{1} and H2subscriptğ»2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{2} (but not Hğ»italic-HH) are known. Introducing the interpolating Hamiltonian,

semantics.annotation: italic-H OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equivalent-to italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta is a positive constant, we can then treat H2subscriptğ»2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{2} as a perturbation when Î²â‰ª1much-less-thanğ›½1italic-beta RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1\beta\ll 1 and treat H1subscriptğ»1italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{1} as a perturbation when Î²â‰«1much-greater-thanğ›½1italic-beta RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1\beta\gg 1, in exactly the same way as in the example (1). A PadÃ© approximant is formed interpolating the perturbative results for large and small Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta. Finally, an approximate solution for the original Hamiltonian Hğ»italic-HH is obtained by setting Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta equal 1 in the PadÃ© approximant. This method will be applied below to calculate quarkonium spectra. Reasonable values for the cğ‘italic-cc and bğ‘italic-bb quark masses are obtained by fitting the calculated levels to their measured values, which demonstrates the legitimacy of this PadÃ© interpolation approach.

Quarkonium refers to the bound state of a heavy quark Qğ‘„italic-QQ (e.g., cğ‘italic-cc or bğ‘italic-bb quark) with its antiquark QÂ¯Â¯ğ‘„OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-Q ARG:end\bar{Q}. It is well known that such systems can be described reasonably well using nonrelativistic quantum mechanics[3]. Various potential energy functions have been used to model the Qâ¢QÂ¯ğ‘„Â¯ğ‘„italic-Q OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-Q ARG:endQ\bar{Q} interaction. It has been found that the potential description is flavor independent, i.e., the same potential describes equally well the câ¢cÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘italic-c OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-c ARG:endc\bar{c} and the bâ¢bÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘italic-b OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-b ARG:endb\bar{b} systems. We consider here a central potential consisting of an attractive Coulomb term and a confining linear potential[4]:

semantics.annotation: italic-V OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-r PUNCT:,

div.p: where Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha and Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda are positive coupling constants. We shall focus on the S states for the purpose of testing the proposed interpolation method. In this case, the Hamiltonian for the radial SchrÃ¶dinger equation is simply

semantics.annotation: italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-mu ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-r PUNCT:,

div.p: where Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu is the reduced mass for the heavy quark Qğ‘„italic-QQ, Î¼=mQ/2ğœ‡subscriptğ‘šğ‘„2italic-mu RELOP:equals italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\mu=m_{Q}/2. Note that Hrsubscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{r} can be expressed as the sum of two exactly solvable Hamiltonians: a Hamiltonian for the Coulomb potential,

semantics.annotation: italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-mu ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: and a Hamiltonian for the linear potential,

semantics.annotation: italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-mu ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-r PERIOD:.

div.p: We have split the kinetic energy term in half so that the â€œeffective massâ€ that appears in HCsubscriptğ»ğ¶italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{C} and in HLsubscriptğ»ğ¿italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{L} is 2â¢Î¼=mQ2ğœ‡subscriptğ‘šğ‘„NUMBER:2 italic-mu RELOP:equals italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end2\mu=m_{Q}.

We may now form the interpolating Hamiltonian, Hrâ¢(Î²)=HC+Î²â¢HLsubscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ›½subscriptğ»ğ¶ğ›½subscriptğ»ğ¿italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{r}(\beta)=H_{C}+\beta H_{L}, and perform perturbative calculations for small Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta as well as for large Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta. We shall summarize the results of our calculation here. Details of the calculation can be found in Ref.[5] where the calculation including the quarkonium P states is also discussed. (For the P states, the centrifugal pontential energy term, lâ¢(l+1)2â¢Î¼â¢r2ğ‘™ğ‘™12ğœ‡superscriptğ‘Ÿ2FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-l OPEN:( italic-l ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-mu italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end\frac{l(l+1)}{2\mu r^{2}}, should be included with HCsubscriptğ»ğ¶italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{C}, resulting in a solvable â€hydrogen-likeâ€ Hamiltonian. Because of the half kinetic energy term, care must be taken to redefine the orbital angular momentum quantum number in order to extract the energy eigenvalues.)

The bound state energies for the S states of Hrâ¢(Î²)subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿğ›½italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)H_{r}(\beta) are computed for small Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta as well as for large Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta to the same order in perturbation theory. Wherever necessary (e.g., integrals involving the Airy functions, the eigenfunctions of HLsubscriptğ»ğ¿italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{L}), terms in the perturbation series are evaluated numerically. In addition, for second and higher order calculations, the infinite series that appear in the perturbation expansions are estimated using the method of acceleration of convergence[6, 5]. A separate PadÃ© approximant is formed interpolating the small and large Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta results from our first, second, and third order calculations. Our estimates for the S state energies are obtained by letting Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta equal 1 in the respective PadÃ© approximant. These are fitted to the corresponding measured values treating Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha, Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda, mcsubscriptğ‘šğ‘italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{c}, mbsubscriptğ‘šğ‘italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{b} as well as the zero-point energies Vcsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{c} (for charmonium) and Vbsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{b} (for bottomonium) as free parameters. We used the data for the J/Ïˆğ½ğœ“italic-J MULOP:divide italic-psiJ/\psi(1S), J/Ïˆğ½ğœ“italic-J MULOP:divide italic-psiJ/\psi(2S), Î¥Î¥Upsilon\Upsilon(1S), Î¥Î¥Upsilon\Upsilon(2S), and Î¥Î¥Upsilon\Upsilon(3S) given in Ref.[7]. When performing the fit, care must be taken to avoid the artificial singularities of the PadÃ© approximant.

The details of the fit results are presented in Table 1. We see that the first-order approximation already produces a rather good fit to the measured S-state energies, although the best fit values for mcsubscriptğ‘šğ‘italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{c} and mbsubscriptğ‘šğ‘italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{b} are somewhat high. The second-order approximation improves the fit quality, reproducing all of the quarkonium S-levels. The fit quality, defined as âˆ‘i(mi(experiment)-mi(calculated))2subscriptğ‘–superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–(experiment)superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–(calculated)2SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:(experiment) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:(calculated) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sum_{i}\left(m_{i}^{\hbox{(experiment)}}-m_{i}^{\hbox{(calculated)}}\right)^{2}, worsens (from less than 1 to 240) as we go to the third-order approximation, primarily due to the increased difficulty to avoid a larger number of unphysical singularities from the PadÃ© approximant in performing the fit. Using the second-order results, our best fit values for mcsubscriptğ‘šğ‘italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{c} and mbsubscriptğ‘šğ‘italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{b} are 1.521 GeV and 5.046 GeV, respectively, to be compared with the values given in Ref.[7]: mc=1.0â¢toâ¢1.6subscriptğ‘šğ‘1.0to1.6italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.0 to NUMBER:1.6m_{c}=1.0~{}{\rm to}~{}1.6 GeV; mb=4.1â¢toâ¢4.5subscriptğ‘šğ‘4.1to4.5italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.1 to NUMBER:4.5m_{b}=4.1~{}{\rm to}~{}4.5 GeV. The best fit values for the parameters in the quarkonium potential (6), Î±=0.4984ğ›¼0.4984italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4984\alpha=0.4984 and Î»=0.1771â¢GeV2ğœ†0.1771superscriptGeV2italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1771 GeV POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\lambda=0.1771~{}{\rm GeV}^{2}, also compare favorably with earlier results: Î±=0.520ğ›¼0.520italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.520\alpha=0.520 and Î»=0.183â¢GeV2ğœ†0.183superscriptGeV2italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.183 GeV POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\lambda=0.183~{}{\rm GeV}^{2} in Ref.[8]; Î±=0.507ğ›¼0.507italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.507\alpha=0.507 and Î»=0.169â¢GeV2ğœ†0.169superscriptGeV2italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.169 GeV POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\lambda=0.169~{}{\rm GeV}^{2} in Ref.[3].

We have also performed a fit with the constraint Vb-Vc=2â¢(mb-mc)subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘2subscriptğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)V_{b}-V_{c}=2(m_{b}-m_{c}) on the model parameters. The results are presented in Table 2. The fit quality in this case is comparable to that of the unconstrained fit and the best fit values of the model parameters differ somewhat from the best fit values of the unconstrained fit, indicating that the found minimum is not sharp and allows for some variation of the quark masses as long as their difference remains equal to half of the difference between the zero-point energies Vbsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{b} and Vcsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{c}. The model parameters appear to be more stable than before as we go from first to second-order PadÃ© interpolation, which corroborates the physical significance of the constraint.

As a final check, we have integrated numerically the SchrÃ¶dinger equation for the quarkonium systems with the second-order best fit values of the parameters to obtain the energy levels. The results are shown in the last column of Table 1. This verifies the validity of the PadÃ© interpolation method.

In conclusion, using quarkonia and a simple two-state model as our testing grounds, we have shown that PadÃ© interpolation can be a powerful method for estimating physical quantities at intermediate values of the coupling constant where perturbative calculations are not reliable. There are many areas for which this method may be applicable. One of which is the K-meson system. The strange quark mass, mssubscriptğ‘šğ‘ italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{s}, has the value such that neither chiral perturbation theory (for small quark masses) nor heavy quark effective theory (for large quark masses) gives a good description of K-meson properties. With PadÃ© interpolation we may be able to obtain a more accurate estimate of the K-meson properties by interpolating the small mssubscriptğ‘šğ‘ italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{s} and large mssubscriptğ‘šğ‘ italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{s} behaviors which can be obtained perturbatively through chiral perturbation theory and heavy quark effective theory, respectively. These issues are being examined by one of us and the results will be reported in the near future[9].
This work was supported in part by the U.S. Department of Energy under grant DE-FG02-84ER40163.

N. Seiberg and E. Witten, Nucl. Phys. B426, 19 (1994); ibid. B431, 484 (1994).
See, e.g., the review by C. Quigg and J. L. Rosner, Phys. Rep. 56, 167 (1979).
E. Eichten, K. Gottfried, T. Kinoshita, J. Kogut, K. D. Lane, and T.-M. Yan, Phys. Rev. Lett. 34, 369 (1975).
J. A. Murakowski, Ph.D. thesis, University of Delaware, 1998 (unpublished).
E. J. Weniger, Computer Physics Reports 10, 189 (1989).
Particle Data Group, R. Barnett et al., Phys. Rev. D 54, 1 (1996).
E. Eichten, K. Gottfried, T. Kinoshita, K. D. Lane, and T.-M. Yan, Phys. Rev. D 21, 203 (1980).
C. N. Leung, â€PadÃ© interpolation II: application to K-mesonsâ€, in preparation.
